title: Storm Lake Times
text:
The Storm Lake Times is a twice-weekly <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a> based in <a href="Storm%20Lake%2C%20Iowa">Storm Lake, Iowa</a>, covering <a href="Buena%20Vista%20County%2C%20Iowa">Buena Vista County</a> and parts of neighboring <a href="Clay%20County%2C%20Iowa">Clay</a>, <a href="Pocahontas%20County%2C%20Iowa">Pocahontas</a>, <a href="Sac%20County%2C%20Iowa">Sac</a>, <a href="Ida%20County%2C%20Iowa">Ida</a> and <a href="Cherokee%20County%2C%20Iowa">Cherokee</a> counties. The newspaper, founded in 1990, is staffed and published by the Cullen family. Editor Art Cullen received the <a href="2017%20Pulitzer%20Prize">2017 Pulitzer Prize</a> in Editorial Writing for a series of editorials on <a href="dark%20money">dark money</a> in <a href="Corporate%20farming">corporate agriculture</a> in Iowa.
History.
John Cullen began publishing "The Storm Lake Times as" a weekly newspaper, on June 29, 1990. It was delivered on Fridays. In 1993, the "Times" moved to daily publication, then to twice weekly the following year. The "Times" became a direct competitor to "The Storm Lake Pilot Tribune", which had been publishing in the town since 1870.
"Times" Editor Art Cullen received the <a href="2017%20Pulitzer%20Prize">2017 Pulitzer Prize</a> in Editorial Writing for a series of editorials on <a href="dark%20money">dark money</a> in corporate agriculture in Iowa. Cullen's coverage of corporate funds being used by the local <a href="public%20utility">public utility</a> to fight a federal lawsuit related to the release of <a href="nitrogen">nitrogen</a> into drinking water earned him national acclaim. The newspaper's coverage of ethnicity-related issues in Storm Lake, where 21 percent of residents are Latino, also earned praise from "<a href="The%20Los%20Angeles%20Times">The Los Angeles Times</a>".
National coverage.
On October 20, 2007, "The Times" was mentioned by "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" and ABC's <a href="George%20Stephanopoulos">George Stephanopoulos</a> for being the first newspaper to endorse a presidential candidate, <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a>, months ahead of the Iowa caucuses.
On May 7, 2008, "The Times" again received national attention for a story written by reporter Jake Kurtz about Dale Davis, a blind World War II veteran who bowled a perfect 300 game at Century Lanes in <a href="Alta%2C%20Iowa">Alta, Iowa</a>.
On November 3, 2009, Art Cullen testified before the <a href="Senate%20Health%2C%20Education%2C%20Labor%20and%20Pensions%20Committee">Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee</a> on the impact of health care costs on small businesses in America. The appearance came at the request of a longtime friend, Senator <a href="Tom%20Harkin">Tom Harkin</a>.
The newspaper is the subject of a 2021 <a href="PBS">PBS</a> "<a href="Independent%20Lens">Independent Lens</a>" documentary film, "<a href="Storm%20Lake%20%28film%29">Storm Lake</a>".
Layout and content.
"The Times" is printed in broadsheet format. A complete online version is available by subscription. There is also a <a href="website">website</a>. Each issue has three sections: Front/News, Sports, and Family & Friends.
An average issue of "The Times" includes 50 or more news and sports photographs, about one-third of them in color. The sports department covers eight high schools (Storm Lake, Storm Lake St. Mary's, Alta, Newell-Fonda, Schaller-Crestland, Sioux Central, Aurelia, Laurens-Marathon) and one college (Buena Vista University). Nearly 600 area cooks have been featured in the “My Favorite Recipes” weekly feature.
Additional special sections include:.
